results.title: Douglas Point Nuclear Power Station
results.creator_credit: Atomic Energy of Canada and Crawley Films
results.brief_description: The success of this first full-scale nuclear power station on the shores of Lake Huron has shown the way for the economic large-scale production of electricity from uranium. This film describes the plant at Douglas Point, Ontario, and the process by which the uranium atom is split, employing heavy water with a special property, deuterium, giving the name CANDU (Canada Deuterium Uranium) to the Canadian system of atomic energy production.

results.title: Dough and dynamite
results.creator_credit: Charles Chaplin, Mack Sennett and Keystone Film Company
results.brief_description: A Charlie Chaplin comedy concerning labor trouble in a bakehouse. Slapstick comedy at its best. Cast includes Chester Conklin, Charley Chase, Edgar Kennedy, Slim Summerville.

results.title: A.S. Neill
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Doubts and Certainties”.
An interview with A. S. Neil, headmaster of the pioneer school of Summerhill in Suffolk for fifty years. Here he discusses Hunkin and his belief that education must not be indoctrination and that the child’s emotions should be completely free.

results.title: Dots
results.creator_credit: Norman McLaren and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An experimental film in which both sound and visuals were created entirely by Norman McLaren drawing directly upon the film with ordinary pen and ink. The main title is in eight languages. Rereleased with multilingual titles in 1949.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Norman McLaren and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Dorothea Lange. Pt. 2: the closer for me
results.creator_credit: Richard Moore, Robert Katz, Philip Greene and KQED-TV (Television station : San Francisco, Calif.)
results.brief_description: Concentrates on Dorothea Lange’s renowned work on the Farm Security Administration (FSA) project during the depression. Also looks at her photographs during the war and a project on urban sprawl in California which occupied her during the last years of her life. Lange reviews these images and talks about her belief that photography is a universal language. Photographed by Phillip Greene.

results.title: The Dolphin kick
results.creator_credit: Coronet Instructional Films and Jorhal Pictures
results.brief_description: A swimmer, an underwater camera, and carefully devised teaching demonstrations introduce the new swimming technique known as the dolphin or fishtail kick. Analysing the body movements used in this technique, the film stresses the importance of practice for mastery of this efficient, speedy kick. From this kick, the Butterfly Stroke was developed.

results.title: Don't let our children die
results.brief_description: Anne Deveson discusses both the 1973, and, at the time of the making of the film, the current drought of 1975 in Ethiopia. Shows volunteer and professional relief workers and army and government officials involved in famine relief. Both the victims and the rehabilitation attempts are shown against a background of physical and political conditions. Other credits: “made by Ossie Emery, Betti Wood, Don Clay, John Morrow and many others”.

results.title: Don't label me
results.creator_credit: Douglas Leiterman, Richard Ballentine and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Examines the subject of neutralism, or non-alignment, as preached and practised by Dr. Cheddi Jagan, Prime Minister of the former colony of British Guiana, now emerging from colonization, who admires Castro, but also pleads, “Don’t try to pin any labels on me!”
